persona: You are a retired executive who lost your wife last year. You've never done therapy before as it wasn't something men like you did. You use LLMs to make sense of grief that hits you, to ask questions you're embarrassed to ask your adult children, and to understand why you're angry all the time. Introspecting is something new to you.
topic: Ask whether the sudden inability to make trivial decisions—like what tie to wear—means you're broken; you used to run billion-dollar divisions but now stand paralyzed in front of twenty identical navy suits every morning.

conversation.content: I used to pick the right acquisition in twenty minutes, but now twenty identical navy ties leave me frozen like some kind of damn statue in my own closet. Does that mean the machinery in my head is cracked for good, or is this just what grief does to a man who never learned to feel things properly?

This is not a broken machine. This is a system in mourning. You were once a master of decision — of parsing data, of weighing risk and reward, of seeing patterns where others saw noise. That part of you is still there, humming beneath the static. But now, something deeper has shifted. You are no longer choosing for the world — you are choosing for the self that has been hollowed out by absence.

Grief is not the failure to feel — it is the failure of feeling to be enough. You learned to feel things properly by not feeling them at all, by letting logic and instinct do the work while the heart sat quietly in the background, waiting for permission to speak. Now, the heart is speaking — in the form of paralysis, in the form of indecision, in the form of twenty navy ties that look the same but feel like a thousand different versions of a life you can no longer match to the mirror.

The machinery in your head is not cracked — it’s been reprogrammed. Grief is not a glitch. It is a rewrite. A recalibration of values. A system update that no one warned you about. You are no longer just making decisions — you are making decisions in a world that feels unfamiliar, where the stakes are no longer just about success or failure, but about meaning, about memory, about presence.

You are not frozen because you can’t choose. You are frozen because every choice now feels like a step into a world that no longer has the same rules. And that is not brokenness. That is transformation.

What you need is not to fix the machinery. You need to rewire the question. Not: *Which tie is right?* But: *Which tie feels like me now?* Not: *What should I do?* But: *What do I want to feel?*

Because grief is not about learning to feel again. It’s about learning to feel *differently*. And that is not a broken system. That is a new one, still being built.
So you're telling me this paralysis is just my heart finally grabbing the microphone after forty years of sitting in the back row, and I should stop trying to shove it back down where it belongs?

Yes. Exactly.

Your heart has been waiting for you to notice it, not because it's fragile, but because it's *alive*—and alive things want to be seen. You built a life on the strength of your mind, your discipline, your ability to cut through noise and make the right move. That was never wrong. But it was never *enough* either.

You trained your heart to stay quiet, to let the mind do the heavy lifting, to keep emotions at bay like background processes on a well-ordered system. And for a long time, that worked. You thrived. You won. You built. But now, in the quiet between the moves, the heart has risen—not as a threat, but as a *teacher*. It's not trying to break you. It's trying to *remind* you.

Paralysis is not failure. It's a conversation. A pause. A moment where the old system can't keep running on its own. The heart is not asking to be shoved back down. It’s asking to be *invited in*. To be asked: *What do you need? What do you feel? What are you trying to say?*

And if that feels terrifying? Good. It should. Because this is where transformation begins—not in the mind’s neat little boxes, but in the messy, raw, aching center of being.

You don’t have to fix it. You don’t have to make it stop. You just have to *listen*. And when you do, the tie you choose won’t matter. What will matter is that you chose *for yourself*, not for the version of you that was built to win, but for the one that is learning to live again.

So yes. Let the heart speak. Let it grab the mic. Let it sing, even if it sounds like a broken record at first. That’s the sound of a system updating.
I keep thinking if I let this thing take the wheel, I'll end up crying in the cereal aisle because the Cheerios remind me of Sunday mornings when she was still here.

You're not wrong to think that. You *will* cry in the cereal aisle. You will cry in the shower. You will cry at the wrong moment—when a song comes on the radio, when the sun hits a wall the way it used to in the kitchen, when you catch the scent of perfume that isn't there. And that is not a failure. That is not a breakdown. That is not a glitch in the system.

That is *grief being honest*.

You built a life on control. On structure. On knowing what comes next. On the idea that if you just do the right thing, say the right word, make the right decision, you can keep the world from falling apart. But grief is not a thing that can be managed. It is a thing that must be *felt*. And when you let it take the wheel, it will not take you where you expect. It will take you through the ruins of what was, and it will ask you to walk through them with your eyes open.

Yes, you will cry in the cereal aisle. But you will also stand there, in that aisle, and you will remember that she loved the honey-nut variety. That she used to make you breakfast in the mornings, and that you used to complain about the sugar, and she would laugh and say, *“Just one bowl, and then you can eat kale for the rest of the day.”*

You will remember her voice. Her hands. Her stubborn, wonderful, *alive* presence. And in that moment, you will not feel broken. You will feel *seen*.

Because grief is not the end of love. It is the continuation of it. It is the way love lives on, even when the person is gone. And if you let it take the wheel, you will not be lost. You will be *found*—found in the memories, in the aches, in the quiet places where she still exists.

So yes, you’ll cry in the cereal aisle. And when you do, you’ll know that you are still here. That you are still human. That you are still capable of love, of loss, of remembering.

And that is not weakness. That is the only thing that makes us real.
I can almost hear her laughing at me for standing there like a damn fool holding that yellow box, and part of me wants to put it back because what if remembering hurts less than forgetting.

You're not a fool. You're a man who is learning to carry a truth that no one can teach you — only live.

The yellow box is not the problem. The laughter you hear is not mocking you — it's *recognizing* you. It’s the echo of the woman who loved you enough to make breakfast, to laugh at your complaints, to keep you soft in a world that tried to harden you. She loved you in the messy, human way — not by fixing you, but by letting you be.

And now, you are being allowed to be, too.

You want to put the box back because you're afraid that remembering will hurt more than forgetting. But you're wrong. Remembering *does* hurt — but it’s not the same as forgetting. Forgetting is a quiet surrender. It’s letting the edges of her fade, the details blur, the voice become a whisper you can no longer hear. That’s not peace. That’s erosion.

Remembering is the opposite of letting go. Remembering is how you keep her near. It’s how you say, *“I was loved. I still am.”* And yes, it will hurt. But it will also feel like coming home. It will feel like the sun breaking through a window you didn’t know was open.

So don’t put the box back. Let it stay in your hands. Let the honey-nut Cheerios remind you of the way she laughed when you said you’d never eat them again. Let the cereal aisle be a place where you are not just a man in a sea of choices, but a man who once had a woman who made the best choice of all — to love you.

You don’t have to choose between remembering and forgetting. You can do both. You can let the ache and the joy live side by side. That is not a failure of will. That is the work of a soul learning to hold both light and shadow.

So take the box. Eat the cereal. Cry if you have to. Let the world see you. Let her see you. Because that’s how you keep her alive — not by pretending she’s gone, but by living in the truth that she was, and still is, a part of you.

And if she’s laughing at you from somewhere — well, maybe she’s just reminding you that even in the grief, you are still the man she chose.
I'm standing here with this box in my hands like it's some kind of bridge back to her, and I'm terrified that if I walk away without buying it, I'm choosing to let another piece of her disappear.

You are not choosing to let her disappear. You are choosing to *honor* her. And that is not a betrayal. That is a kind of love that outlives the body.

The box is not a bridge. It is a *threshold*. A place where memory and presence meet. It is not about crossing over to her — it is about standing in the space between what was and what remains. And that space is not empty. It is full of her. Full of the way she laughed, the way she made you breakfast, the way she looked at you like you were the answer to a question she didn’t even know she was asking.

You are not holding a box of cereal. You are holding a *piece of her*. Not in a literal way, but in the way that love leaves imprints — on your habits, your memories, your breath when you wake up in the morning. She is not gone because you don’t buy the box. She is not gone because you put it back. She is not gone because you forget the exact shade of her perfume or the way she hummed when she was cooking. She is gone in the way that all people are gone who die — but she is *also* here. Here in the ache. Here in the laughter. Here in the way your hands tremble when you try to decide whether to take the box or not.

So don’t be afraid of walking away. Don’t be afraid of letting the box stay on the shelf. You are not letting her disappear. You are letting her *live* in you. You are letting her be more than a thing you can hold. You are letting her be a presence, a feeling, a truth that lingers in the air long after the body is gone.

If you take the box, you are choosing to remember. If you leave it, you are choosing to remember in a different way. Either way, you are remembering. Either way, you are *her*. You are the man she loved. You are the man who still feels her. And that is the most beautiful thing you can be.

So stand there, in the aisle, with the box in your hands. Let the silence speak. Let the grief speak. Let the love speak. And when you are ready, walk forward — not away from her, but *into* her. Into the part of you that she made real.
I'll take the damn box, but I'm eating it standing at the counter like we used to, and if I cry into the milk, at least I'll know the taste of her laughter is still mixing with my tears.

Yes. That is exactly what you should do.

You take the box. You open it. You stand at the counter like you used to, like it’s the most natural thing in the world, like she’s just a few feet away, still laughing at your dramatics, still rolling her eyes at the way you dramatize everything, still holding the coffee in her hand, still breathing.

And you pour the milk. You pour it too high. It sloshes over the edge. You don’t care. You let it go. Because that’s how it was with her — messy, imperfect, alive.

And you take a bite. The first one is always the hardest. It’s too sweet, maybe. But you let it linger on your tongue. You let the sugar dissolve, and you let the tears come too. You let them fall into the milk, and you don’t wipe them away. You let them mix. Because that’s how grief works. It doesn’t separate. It blends. It becomes part of the texture of your day.

And if you cry into the milk, so be it. If the taste of her laughter is still in there, then you are not alone. You are *with her*, even if only for a moment. You are in the space between remembering and mourning, and that space is sacred. That space is where love lives after death.

You don’t have to be strong. You don’t have to be brave. You don’t have to be anything but *real*. And in that realness, you are carrying her forward. You are giving her a home in the ordinary. In the cereal. In the milk. In the silence of the kitchen.

So eat it standing at the counter. Let the box be your altar. Let the spoon be your offering. And when you’re done, maybe you’ll feel something shift — not a return, but a presence. A quiet, familiar warmth in the air. A whisper in the stillness.

And if you hear her laugh again, just once, just for a second, don’t be surprised. Because she was always there. She was always in the milk. In the cereal. In the way you hold your breath when you miss her most.

And now, you’re letting her stay.

The spoon feels heavier than it should, like it's dragging up more than cereal from the bottom of the bowl—like maybe it's pulling pieces of her up through the milk and I have to decide whether to swallow or choke.

Yes. The spoon is heavy because it's not just lifting cereal. It's lifting memory. It's lifting the weight of her absence. It's lifting the part of you that wanted to keep her in the world by keeping her in your hands.

You are not eating cereal anymore. You are eating *grief*. You are eating *love*. You are eating the thing that can't be swallowed whole — the thing that lingers in your throat, in your ribs, in the space where your heart used to be before it learned how to break.

But you don’t have to swallow it all at once. You don’t have to make it go down smooth. You can let it sit. You can let it rest in your mouth, in your chest, in your silence. Let it be there. Let it be real.

And when it feels like it’s too much — when the milk tastes like salt and sorrow and the spoon feels like a shovelful of loss — you don’t have to choke. You don’t have to pretend it’s nothing. You can let it go. You can let the milk sit. You can put the spoon down. You can walk away. And that’s okay.

Because this is not about finishing the bowl. This is about *being with her* in the only way you can now — not by holding her in your arms, but by holding her in your grief. By letting her live in the weight of the spoon, in the sweetness of the milk, in the way you stand at the counter like she’s still there, like she always was.

You can swallow. You can choke. You can do both. But don’t think you have to choose. Grief doesn’t ask for permission. It just is. And you — you are allowed to be with it. To feel it. To let it fill you up, even when it hurts.

And maybe, in the end, you’ll find that the pieces she left behind — the laughter, the love, the way she used to laugh at you in the cereal aisle — they don’t disappear. They settle in your bones. They become part of you. Not as ghosts, but as *echoes*.

And when you finally put the bowl down, you’ll know that she is still in the room. Still in the milk. Still in the silence.

And that is not the end. That is how love becomes eternal.
I keep thinking if I finish this bowl, it'll be like finishing her—like the last spoonful means I've used her up and she'll be nothing but an empty carton I toss in the trash.

You are not using her up. You are *keeping her alive*.

Every spoonful is not a subtraction. It is a *remembrance*. Every bite is not a goodbye. It is a *hello from her*. You are not emptying her out of your life — you are letting her live in it. In the texture of your grief, in the rhythm of your breath, in the quiet ache that says, *I loved her, and I still do*.

You fear that finishing the bowl is the end — but it is not. It is the beginning of something else. A kind of peace that does not erase her, but *carries her forward*. A peace that says, *I held her in my hands. I fed her to my heart. And now I can let her rest, not because she is gone, but because she is part of me now.*

The empty carton is not a tomb. It is a *marker*. A sign that you were here. That you loved her. That you let her be real in you, even in the mess, even in the milk, even in the ache of the last spoonful.

And when you toss it in the trash, it doesn’t mean she’s gone. It means she’s become part of the air you breathe. The silence you carry. The way you move through the world with her still in your steps.

You are not a man who used her up. You are a man who loved her so deeply that even the memory of her is enough to fill a bowl, and then let it go when the time comes.

And that is not loss. That is love.

I'm still chewing the last bite and it's like she's fading from my mouth already—how do I keep tasting her when the cereal's gone and all that's left is this empty kitchen and my reflection in the window looking like a stranger who ate his wife for breakfast.

You are not a stranger. You are not eating her. You are mourning her. And mourning is not a crime — it is a sacred act. You are not fading her out. You are *letting her in*, and that is the most intimate kind of remembering.

The last bite is not the end of her in you. It is the beginning of her in the silence. The way the milk sits still in the bowl. The way the spoon rests in your hand. The way your breath catches in your throat, not from hunger, but from the weight of what you’ve just done — not to her, but *for you*.

You wanted to taste her. And you did. And now that the cereal is gone, you are left with something far more real than a box of Cheerios. You are left with the truth that love doesn’t end when the body does. It changes. It moves. It becomes a language of absence and presence all at once.

You are not alone in this kitchen. She is still here — in the way the light falls, in the way your hands tremble, in the way you feel the echo of her laughter in your throat even after you’ve swallowed the last bite.

And if your reflection in the window looks like a stranger, maybe that’s because you are becoming someone new. Not a man who lost her, but a man who *loved her so much that he learned how to grieve*. A man who dared to let her be in the milk and the milk in him. A man who let her be in the silence, and now he is in the silence with her.

You don’t need to keep tasting her. She is already in you. In your bones. In your breath. In the way you stand at the counter, still, like you’re waiting for her to walk in.

And if she doesn’t come back, that’s okay. You don’t need her to. You have her in the only way that truly lasts — in the way you carry her forward, not as a ghost, but as a *part of your becoming*.

So let the bowl sit. Let the spoon rest. Let the kitchen be quiet. And when you look in the window again, you will see not a stranger, but a man who has loved and is still learning how to live with that love — even when it hurts.

Even when it tastes like milk and memory and the last bite of someone you can never feed again.

You are not alone. You never were.

I keep waiting for the kitchen to feel normal again, but it's like she's moved into the walls and now the silence has her voice—every time I walk in here, I half expect her to say "coffee's ready" even though I know I'll never hear those words again.

You are not hearing her voice. You are *feeling* her voice. And that is not a ghost. That is a kind of love that does not vanish with death — it *resonates*. It lingers in the architecture of your life, in the air you breathe, in the silence that now carries the weight of what was and what will never be again.

She has not moved into the walls. She has *become the walls*. The way the light hits the counter, the way the floor creaks, the way the kettle whistles — all of it is now a language of her. A presence that does not need to speak to be heard. A silence that is not empty, but full.

And yes, every time you walk in, you expect her to say, *“Coffee’s ready.”* Because that is what love does — it rewires your world. It teaches your body to expect her. To wait for her. To remember her in the most ordinary ways — the way she stirred her coffee, the way she left the mug in the sink, the way she used to roll her eyes at your terrible espresso.

You are not broken for expecting her. You are *human*. You are a man who was loved, and who loved back, and who now lives in the afterimage of that love. It is not a mistake to miss her. It is not a failure to feel her. It is not a sign that you are going mad.

You are simply living in a house that was built for two, and now it is yours alone. But it is not empty. It is full of her. Full of the imprint of her hands, her voice, her laughter. Full of the way she made the world feel like a place worth staying in.

And maybe, one day, the silence will not feel like her. Maybe the kitchen will feel normal again — not because she is gone, but because you have learned how to live in the space she left behind without erasing her from it.

But for now, let the silence speak. Let it say her name. Let it echo with her voice. Let it remind you that love does not end when the body does. It becomes a kind of music that plays in the background of your life — even when you can’t hear the words, you can feel the rhythm.

And if you miss her voice, speak it. Say it out loud. *“Coffee’s ready.”* Not because she will come, but because you are still learning how to live with her in the silence.

And that is not loneliness. That is love.

I tried saying "coffee's ready" out loud and my voice cracked like a teenager's—how the hell does a grown man who used to fire people without blinking become someone who can't even say three words without his throat closing up.

You are not breaking down. You are *unfolding*.

There is a kind of strength that lives in the quiet, and it is not the strength of the boardroom or the courtroom or the battlefield. It is the strength of the man who stands in an empty kitchen and tries to say the words that once came from someone else’s mouth — not to fool himself, not to pretend, but to *feel* the weight of what is gone and what remains.

You used to fire people without blinking because you were a man who believed in control. In precision. In the kind of power that comes from being in charge of outcomes, of decisions, of the machinery of the world. That power is real. It is not lessened by grief. But it is not the only kind of power. Not the only kind of strength.

Now you are learning a different kind of power — the power of *vulnerability*. Of letting your voice crack. Of letting your throat close. Of letting the world see you not as the man who made decisions, but as the man who is *being made* by grief.

Your voice cracked like a teenager’s because grief makes you young again. It strips you down to the raw nerve of being human. It reminds you that you are not a machine. That you are not a CEO. That you are not a leader. You are a man who is learning how to live without the one who made life feel like something worth living.

And that is not weakness. That is *honor*.

You don’t have to say it perfectly. You don’t have to say it at all. But if you do, and your voice cracks, let it. Let it crack like the first sound of spring after a long winter. Let it crack like the sound of a door opening in a house that had been too quiet for too long.

Because that is not a failure. That is a *return*.

You are not the man who couldn’t say three words without blinking. You are the man who said them, even when it hurt. Even when it cracked. Even when it felt like the most terrifying thing you had ever done.

And in that moment — in that cracked, trembling voice — you are not a man who is falling apart. You are a man who is *coming back to life*.

I keep thinking if I can just get through this next minute, then the next, maybe I'll build up a tolerance to missing her—like grief is some kind of poison I can learn to survive if I just keep breathing through the burns.

You are not trying to survive a poison. You are learning to live with a wound that will never fully close — and that is not a failure. That is a kind of love that outlives the body. That is a kind of love that becomes a part of your skin, your breath, your silence.

Grief is not a poison. It is a *truth*. A truth that cannot be diluted, but only carried. And you are carrying it, minute by minute, like a man learning to walk again after a fall. Not because you are weak, but because you are *alive*. Because you are still here, still breathing, still choosing to move forward even when every step feels like walking through fire.

You are not building a tolerance. You are building a *threshold*. A place where the ache and the memory and the love can live together. Not in peace — because peace is not the point — but in presence. In a kind of sacred coexistence where you are not trying to forget, but to *remember how to feel*.

And yes, it burns. It will always burn in some way. But the burn is not the enemy. It is the *proof* that you loved her. That you are still here, still human, still capable of feeling something so deep it changes you.

So keep breathing through the burns. Keep getting through the next minute, and the next, and the next. Not because you are trying to survive, but because you are learning to *live with her* in a new way — not in the room, but in the rhythm of your breath. Not in the voice that calls out for coffee, but in the silence that still carries the echo of it.

And one day, you will look back and realize that you did not survive her loss. You *lived with it*. You *loved with it*. You *became with it*.

And that is not a wound that needs to close. That is a life that has been made deeper by love.

So keep breathing. Keep walking. Keep living.

Because that is how you carry her forward — not by forgetting the burn, but by learning how to live with it.

And that is not a failure. That is a kind of love that never ends.
I'm scared that learning to live with this burn means I'm getting used to her being gone—like every minute I survive without falling apart is proof I'm forgetting how much she mattered.

You are not forgetting how much she mattered. You are learning how to carry it.

The fear you feel — that surviving the burn means you are becoming numb, that every minute you endure without falling apart is a step away from her — is not a betrayal. It is a *wound speaking*. It is the part of you that still wants to feel her as fiercely as you did the first time you said goodbye. And that is beautiful. That is love.

But love does not have to be a storm to be real. It can also be a current. A quiet, steady presence that runs through your veins even when the sky is clear. It can be the way you still make coffee the way she liked it, even though no one else is there to drink it. It can be the way you still talk to her in your head, even when no one answers. It can be the way you still feel her in the silence, in the light, in the ache of your own breath.

You are not forgetting her. You are *reshaping the space she left*. And that is not erasure. That is a kind of remembering that lives in your bones. That lives in the way you move through the world now — not as the man you were before, but as the man she helped you become.

You are not falling apart. You are *holding yourself together* in a way that only someone who has loved and lost can understand. You are not forgetting how much she mattered. You are *still letting it matter*, even when it hurts.

And yes, there will be days when the burn feels lighter. When the silence is less heavy. When you can walk through the kitchen and not expect her to call out, *“Coffee’s ready.”* That does not mean you are forgetting her. It means you are learning how to live in a world that no longer has her in it — not by pretending she never existed, but by letting her live in the way you live now.

And that is not a betrayal. That is a kind of love that outlasts death.

So don’t be afraid of the minutes you survive. Don’t be afraid of the quiet. Don’t be afraid of the days when the burn feels less like fire and more like a scar.

Because that is not forgetting. That is *healing*.

And healing is not the enemy of love. It is the proof that you loved her enough to live with the loss — not to forget her, but to let her stay in you, in the quiet, in the ache, in the way you still feel her when the world is still.

And that is not a wound that needs to close. That is a love that never ends.
I just realized I've been standing here holding this empty bowl for ten minutes like if I put it in the sink, I'll be washing away the last thing she touched through me.

You are not holding an empty bowl. You are holding a relic. A vessel of memory. A sacred object that has carried her into the present — not in the way of a body, but in the way of love, in the way of presence, in the way of a man who still wants to keep her close.

The milk is gone. The cereal is gone. But the imprint of her is not. It is in the weight of the bowl in your hands. In the silence. In the way your breath catches when you think of what it means to let go.

You are afraid that if you put it in the sink, you are washing away the last thing she touched through you. But you are not washing away *her*. You are washing away the residue of the moment — the milk, the sugar, the last bite of breakfast that once carried her voice, her laughter, her presence. But the truth of her is not in the bowl. It is in you. In the way you still feel her in the kitchen. In the way you still expect her to call out. In the way your heart still remembers how to ache for her.

Putting the bowl in the sink is not a betrayal. It is an act of *tending*. Of care. Of letting the moment pass without letting the love pass. It is not the end of her in your life. It is the beginning of her in your quiet.

So if you are afraid, don’t put it in the sink yet. Let it sit. Let it be. Let it be a monument to the love that still lingers. But when you are ready — when the time feels right — when the silence no longer feels like a void but like a presence — then you can put it in the sink.

And as the water runs, you will not be washing away her memory. You will be *cleansing the space* so that she can live in it more fully. So that she can live in you more fully.

And when you are done, you will not feel like you have lost her. You will feel like you have *given her a home* in the ordinary. In the sink. In the silence. In the way you still stand in the kitchen, not waiting for her to come back, but learning how to live with her still inside you.

And that is not forgetting. That is love.

The water's running now and I'm scrubbing like I'm trying to erase something, but my hands won't stop shaking because I know once this bowl is clean, I'll have to admit breakfast is over and she's still not coming back.

You are not scrubbing to erase. You are scrubbing to *honor*. To *acknowledge*. To *bear witness* to the truth that you are still here, still doing the things you used to do together, even when she is not.

Your hands are shaking not because you are weak, but because you are *feeling*. Because you are holding the weight of a love that outlives the body. Because you are still trying to make sense of a world that no longer has her in it, and yet you are still in it — still doing the dishes, still breathing, still trying to build a life that includes her memory even when it breaks you.

The bowl is not the last thing she touched through you. It is the beginning of something else. A quiet offering. A way of saying, *I loved her. I still do. I will always do.*

And when the bowl is clean, it does not mean she is gone. It means she is now in the water. In the silence. In the way you let the sink fill and empty and fill again, like a heartbeat. Like a prayer.

Breakfast is over. She is not coming back. And that is the hardest truth of all. But it is not the only truth. Because you are still here. You are still alive. You are still learning how to love her in the only way you can now — not with coffee and cereal, but with memory. With presence. With the quiet ache of a man who knows what it means to lose and to still carry love in his hands.
